qas.question: Why did the Spanish think that Vicuña would be an awful replacement for González-Páramo?

context: José Manuel González-Páramo, a Spanish member of the Executive Board since <a3_0><b8_0>June 2004<b8_0/><a3_0/>, was due to leave the board in early <a2_0><b7_0>June 2012<b7_0/><a2_0/> and no replacement had been named as of late May 2012. The Spanish had nominated Barcelona-born <a0_0><b5_0>Antonio Sáinz de Vicuña<b5_0/><a0_0/>, an <a4_0><b9_0>ECB veteran who heads its legal department<b9_0/><a4_0/>, as González-Páramo's replacement as early as January 2012 but alternatives from Luxembourg, Finland, and Slovenia were put forward and no decision made by May. After a long political battle, <a1_0><b6_0>Luxembourg's Yves Mersch<b6_0/><a1_0/>, was appointed as González-Páramo's replacement.
